fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Roughly, how to make the titular noodles, according to my dad:

fr:ol.fr:li: Appropriate amount of flour in the bowl (but he tends to use the stainless steel pan).
Add some salt to the flour.
Slowly stir in water until it all has a flaky texture.
Work the flaky flour all together into a ball.
Knead the ball some, then wait another 10 minutes. Maybe repeat this a couple of times, the longer the waits the better.
Sprinkle some dry flour and roll the ball out.
Let it sit for a few minutes, then roll it out more, until it's suitably thin.
Cut the dough into thin strips.
Pull each strip into long noodles. Fold and pull more if possible.
All into boiling water at once, for a minute or two. Once it's in, wangjangle with chopsticks immediately to prevent sticking.
Eat with toppings, such as hot chili oil (must), pressed garlic (highly preferred), and greens and meat.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: I was surprised to find it possible to properly type (though not directly via Rime) and render the character 𰻞 (bíang) when recording a recipe for 𰻞𰻞麵 from my dad, since I was, for whatever reason, under the impression that it wasn't part of Unicode. Apparently, it was added in 2020 in Unicode 13.0 as one of the codepoints (precisely, U+30EDE; there's also 𰻝 as U+30EDD) in CJK Unified Ideographs Extension G, the first block of the Tertiary Ideographic Plane.

This block also includes 𱁬 (taito; daito; otodo; U+3106C), an 84-stroke behemoth made by sticking 䨺 (tai; U+4A3A; itself three clouds 雲 together, meaning "cloudy") and 龘 (tou; U+9F98; three dragons 龍, meant to resemble a dragon flying or climbing). It's a Japanese-coined character, or kokuji (国字), but the origins are fairly uncertain. In the early 1960s, a man showed a namecard with this surname to the staff of a brokerage office... or so it goes according to the 1981 姓氏の語源, an etymological dictionary of surnames. Some scholars think it's an erroneous ghost letter. 䨺龘, written separately, was perhaps an alias. In any case, it's now the name of a series of ramen shops starting in Kita-Matsudo (北松戸) in Chiba. I think I'd like to go there sometime.

It seems like some netizens have borrowed the character into Chinese, developing humorous neologisms like 𱁬𪚥 (tài zhé; the latter character meaning "verbose"), meaning something like "excessively complicated (of a Chinese character)". One has to zoom in 200% to make anything of it.

In Chinese, there's also 䲜 ("abundance of fish"; U+4C9C) and 䨻 ("roar of thunder"; U+4A3B). In Japanese, there's 𰽔 (kagami; U+30F54), which seems to me like a bewildering room of many mirrors. Maybe the folks working on the Noto CJK fonts will get to it one day.
Here are some new characters I'd like to propose, to further enrich the space of overly dense and illegible ideographs and make the Unicode people very sad:
A quadriplication of 墓 ("grave"), meaning, of course, a graveyard.
鰞 ("squid") + 鯨 ("whale"), meaning a fight between a sperm whale and a colossal squid.
炎 ("blaze") + 森 ("forest"), meaning a forest fire and pronounced カリフォルニア.

This is, I suppose, something of an exaltation of larks, and I'm reminded of my copy of James Lipton's book (it must be somewhere in the boxes). It seems to me good sense to take
(a quadriplication of 烏, "crow") to mean a murder of crows, and to extend this principle to any other noun.
